text: The flakes drift lazily down toward us. Our angle looks s up. Now an angle looking steeply down: the snow falls not qui away to collect on a foreground chimneypot and on the little shtetl street tha maplike below us. It is night, and quiet, and the street is deserted except one man who walks away from us, his valenki squeaking in the fresh snow. He carries b branches on one shoulder and has a hatchet tucked into his belt. We cut down to street level. The man walks toward us, bea and bundled against the cold. Smiling, he mutters in Yiddish-the dialogue subtitl
What a marvel... what a marvel...
As its door opens and the man enters.
Dora!

Yes... The man crosses to the stove with his bundle of wood. The continues: 2 . Can you help me with the ice? The man dumps the wood into a box by the stove as his wif with an ice pick. . I expected you hours ago.
You can't imagine what just happened. I was coming back on the Lublin road when the wheel came off the cart thank heavens it was the way back and I'd already sold th geese!
How much?
Fifteen groshen, but that's not the story. I was struggli set the cart upright when a droshky approaches from the direction of Lvov. How lucky, you think, that someone is out this late.
Yes, very remarkable.

But that's the least of it! He stops to help me; we talk this, we talk of that-it turns out this is someone you kn Traitle Groshkover! His wife stares at him as he beams. He takes the stare as a sign that she can't place the nam . You know, REB GROSHKOVER! Pesel Bunim's uncle! The chacham from Lodz, who studied under the Zohar reb in Krakow! Still she stares. Then, quietly:
God has cursed us.
What?
Traitle Groshkover has been dead for three years. Laughter erupts from the man but, as his wife continues t at him, he strangles on it. Quiet. Wind whistles under the eaves. The man says quietly:
Why do you say such a thing! I saw the man! I talked to h

You talked to a dybbuk. Traitle Groshkover died of typhus in Pesel Bunim's house. Pesel told me-she sat shiva for him. They stare at each through a silence broken only by the s of the quickening wind. A rap at the door. Neither immediately responds. Finally, to her husband: Who is it?
For some soup, to warm himself. The wind moans. He helped me, Dora!

We are looking in from the outside as it unlatches and cr in, opened by the husband in the foreground, who has arranged his face into a strai look of greeting. In the background the wife stares, hollow-eyed.
REB GROSHKOVER! You are welcome here! Reverse on REB GROSHKOVER: a short, merry-looking fellow a bifurcated beard and a silk hat and spectacles. He gives a little squeal of deli

You are too kind, Velvel! Too kind! He steps into the house and sees the wife staring at him. And you must be Dora! So much I have heard of you! Yes, your cheeks are pink and your legs are stout! What a wife you have! The husband chuckles nervously.
Yes! A ray of sun, a ray of sun! Sit!
My husband said he offered you soup.
Yes, but I couldn't possibly eat this late, or I'd have nightmares. No, no: no soup for me!
I knew it. REB GROSHKOVER laughs.
I see! You think I'm fat enough already! He settles, chuckling, into his chair, but Dora remains s

No. A dybbuk doesn't eat. 5 REB GROSHKOVER stares at her, shocked. The wife returns the stare. The husband looks from wife to REB GROSHKOVER, apprehensi A heavy silence. REB GROSHKOVER bursts into pealing laughter.
What a wife you have! He wipes away tears of merriment; the husband relaxes, ev to smile.

I assure you, REB GROSHKOVER, it's nothing personal; she heard a story you had died, three years ago, at Pesel Bunim's house. This is why she think you are a dybbuk; I, of course, do not believe in such things. I am a rational man. REB GROSHKOVER is still chuckling.
Oh my. Oh my yes. What nonsense. And even if there were spirits, certainly... He thumps his chest. I am not one of them!

Pesel always worried. Your corpse was left unattended for many minutes when Pesel's father broke shiva and left the room-it must have been then that the Evil One- She breaks off to spit at the mention of the Evil One. -took you! REB GROSHKOVER is terribly amused: 6
"My corpse!" Honestly! What a wife you have!

Oh yes? Look, husband... She steps forward to the Reb, who looks enquiringly up at They were preparing the body. Pesel's father shaved one check... As his eyes roll down to look at her hand, she draws it a his smooth right cheek. Then he left the room. He came back, and shaved the other... She reaches across to the other cheek, REB GROSHKOVER's e following her hand- You were already gone! -and drags her hand across. A bristly sound. REB GROSHKOVER laughs.

I shaved hastily this morning and missed a bit-by you thi makes me a dybbuk? He appeals to the husband: It's true, I was sick with typhus when I stayed with Peselle, but I recovered, as you can plainly see, and now I-hugh! The wife steps back. REB GROSHKOVER looks slowly down at his own chest in whic wife has just planted an ice pick. REB GROSHKOVER stares at the ice pick. The wife stares. 7 The husband stares. Suddenly, REB GROSHKOVER bursts out laughing: What a wife you have! The husband can manage only a shocked whisper:
Woman, what have you done? REB GROSHKOVER again looks down at his chest, which again him to laughter. He shakes his head.
Why would she do such a thing? He looks up. I ask you, Velvel, as a rational man: which of us is possessed?
What do you say now about spirits? He is unharmed!
On the contrary! I don't feel at all well. And indeed, blood has begun to soak through his vest. He chuckles with less energy. One does a mitzvah and this is the thanks one gets?
Dora! Woe, woe! How can such a thing be!

Perhaps I will have some soup. I am feeling weak... He rises to his feet but totters. Or perhaps I should go... 8 He smiles weakly at Dora.. One knows when one isn't wanted. He walks unsteadily to the door, opens it with some effor staggers out into the moaning wind and snow to be swallowed by the night. The wife and husband stare at the door banging in the win
Dear wife. We are ruined. Tomorrow they will discover the body. All is lost.
Nonsense, Velvel... She walks to the door... Blessed is the Lord. Good riddance to evil and shuts it a the wind.

A drumbeat thumps in the black. Music blares: the Jefferson Airplane. Grace Slick's voice When the truth is found to be lies And all the hope inside you dies Don't you want somebody to love. . . An image fades in slowly, but even up full it is dim: som of round, dull white shape with a small black pinhole center. This white half-globe plug set in a flesh-toned field. The flesh tone glows translucently, backlit. We ar toward the white plug and, as we do so, the music grows louder still.

9 A pull back-a reverse on the preceding push in-from the c white plastic earpiece of a transistor radio. The Jefferson Airplane continues o the cut but becomes extremely compressed. The pull back reveals that the earp is lodged in someone's ear and trails a white cord. We drift down the cord to find the radio at its other end we do so we hear, live in the room, many voices speaking a foreign language in unison. apparently. The radio is on a desktop but hidden from in front by the held open before it. The book is written in non-Roman characters. We are in Hebrew school. The boy who is listening to the transistor radio-DANNY Go at a hinge-topped desk in a cinderblock classroom whose rows of desks are o by other boys and girls of about twelve years of age. It is dusk and the ro flourescent-lit. At the front of the room a gray-haired man in a worn suit tie addresses the class. DANNY straightens one leg so that he may dig into a pocke an eye on the TEACHER to make sure he isn't being watched, he eases something out: A twenty-dollar bill.
Mee yodayah? Reuven? Rifkah? Mah zeh "anakim"? Efsheh mashooach ba-avodah?

At the cut to the light the Jefferson Airplane music jump full. The light resolves into a multi-flared image of a blinking eye. Reverse: the inside of a human ear. Fleshy whorls finely a cavity receding to dark. Objective on the DOCTOR's office: the DOCTOR is peering t a lightscope into the ear of an early-middle-aged man, LARRY Gopnik. The Jefferson Airplane music continues. 10
Uh-huh.

Close on Hebrew characters being scribbled onto the black as the TEACHER talks. The TEACHER, talking. A bored child, staring off. His point-of-view: a blacktopped parking lot with a few o school busses, beyond it a marshy field, and distant suburban bungalows. Close on another child staring at something through droop eyelids. His point-of-view: very close on the face of a classroom We hear its electrical hum. Its red sweep-second hand crawls around the dial ver slowly. DANNY Gopnik hisses:

Fagle!.. . The TEACHER drones on, writing on the blackboard. DANNY's flit from the TEACHER to the student sitting kitty-corner in front of him-a husky with shaggy hair. He hasn't heard the prompt. . Fagle! The TEACHER turns from the blackboard and DANNY leans bac front, folding the twenty up small behind his book.
Ahnee rotzeh lalechet habait hakisai. Mee yodayah? Misaviv tamid anachnoo tamid... The clock-watching child, eyelids sinking, is beginning t out of one side of his mouth.
11 The light again flaring the lens. Reverse: looking into a pupil. Objective: the DOCTOR looking through his scope into LARR eye.
Mm-hmm.
A bored child is excavating a bugger from his nose. The TEACHER turns back to the chalkboard to circle someth
Fagle!
Hamrah oomoh- He interrupts himself briefly to make a couple of phlegm- sounds. He resumes: . Hamrah oomoh meshiach oomshel zal?
The DOCTOR palpates LARRY's midriff, digging his fingers the hairy, baggy flesh. DOCTOR's Voice Uh-huh. We'll do some routine X-rays.
A young girl holds a hank of her bangs in front of her fa separating out individual hairs to examine them for split ends.
Ahnoo ahnoo mah? Mah? Talmidim? D'vorah? 12
Ahnee to yodayah. The TEACHER begins to pace the desk aisles, looking back forth among the students.

Mee yodayah? The bugger-seeker, having succesfully withdrawn a bugger, drapes it over the sharp end of his pencil, to what end we cannot know. DANNY, apprehensively eyeing the TEACHER, slides the twen the transistor radio's cover-sleeve.

A huge white rubberized cone, pointed directly at us. We hear a rush of static and the DOCTOR's voice filtered a talk-back: DOCTOR's Voice Hold still. Wider: LARRY is in his shorts lying on his back on an exa table covered by a sheet of tissue paper. The X-ray cone is pointed at the middle body. There is a brief sci-fi-like machine hum. It clicks off.
The clock-watching student's head is making descending bo his chest.

Nefsheh shelach hamilamid-eh?! The TEACHER's circuit of the classroom has taken him arou DANNY. DANNY's book lies face-down on the desk, covering the radio, but white cord snakes out from under it up to his ear. The TEACHER yanks at the cord. 13 The cord pops out of its jack and the Jefferson Airplane tinnily from beneath the book of torah stories. The TEACHER lifts the book to expose the jangling radio. Outraged, the TEACHER projects above the music: . Mah zeh? ! Mah zeh? ! Some of the students are singing along; a couple beat rhy on their desks. . Shechet, talmidim! Anachnoo lo cam zeh b'bait sefer! Shechet bivakasha! Three other students join in a chorus:
Shechet! Shechet bivakasha! The nodding student's head droops ever lower. Other students join in the chant:
The nodding student's chin finally reaches, and settles o chest, and he gives a long snorfling inhale of sleep.
LARRY, now fully clothed, is seated across from the DOCTO The DOCTOR is looking at his file. He absently taps a cig out of a pack and lights up. He nods as he smokes, looking at the file.
Well, I-sorry. He holds the pack toward LARRY. 14
No thanks.
Well, you're in good health. How're Judith and the kids?
Good. Everyone's good. You know. The DOCTOR takes a long suck.
Good. Daniel must be-what? About to be bar mitzvah?
Two weeks.
Well, mazel tov. They grow up fast, don't they?

The portrait, old, in an ornate gilt frame, is of a middl rabbi with a small neat mustache and round spectacles. He wears a tallis hood-sty a phylactery box is strapped to his forehead. A plaque set into the frame ide the man as Rabbi Minda. Wider shows that the portrait hangs in the Hebrew school office, a white cinderblock room. It is quiet. The only sound is a deep e hum. Just visible behind the principal's desk, upon which is a stack of books and a name plate identifying the occupant as MAR TURCHIK, is the top a man's head-an old man, with a few whispy white hairs where his yarmulka is DANNY, seated opposite, pushes up from his slouch to bett across the desk. We boom up to show more of the principal. He is short. He a white shirt and hoist-up pants that come to just below his armpits. He ha eyeglasses. He fiddles with the transistor radio, muttering:
Hmm... eh... nu? 15 He experiments with different dials on the radio. DANNY nervously watches.
You put the- The old man holds up one hand.
In ivrit. (In Hebrew)

Um... The old man looks down at the little earpiece pinched bet two fingers. He examines it as a superstitious native might a Coca-Cola bottle. The source of the electrical hum: a wall clock whose red hand crawls around the dial very, very slowly. The Reb continues to squint at the earpiece. DANNY sighs. He encourages:
Yeah, you- The principal's tone is harder:

In ivrit! This time his cold look holds until he is sure that the a has registered. He looks back down at the earpiece. We hear the door open. The principal ignores it. An old woman walks slowly in with a teacup chattering on She has thick eyeglasses. She wears thick flesh-colored support hose. S slow, short steps toward the desk. The principal is studying the radio. 16

Mneh... The old woman continues to take slow short steps toward h The tableau looks like a performance-art piece. She reaches the desk and sets the teacup down. She summon couple of phlegm- hawking rasps and turns to go. She takes slow short steps toward the door. The principal raises the earpiece experimentally toward h Close on his hairy, wrinkled ear as his trembling fingers in the earpiece. The i f ngers push and wobble and tamp the earpiece into plac and then do some more pushing and wobbling and tamping. The principal keeps DANNY fixed with a stare as his hand drops from his ear, ready to reach back up should the earpiece loosen. .mneh... Satisfied that neither the student nor the earpiece are a to make any sudden moves, he looks down at the radio. He turns a dial. Faintly and tinnily from the earpiece we hear the compres jangle of rock music. The rabbi stares blankly, listening. DANNY slumps, looking warily at the rabbi. The rabbi continues to stare down at the radio. The compr rock music jangles on. The rabbi is expressionless, mouth slightly open, listeni Tableau: anxious student, earplugged spiritual leader. Muffled, from the outer office, the hawking of phlegm.
We are behind a man who writes equations on a chalkboard, at work and hand quickly waggling. Periodically he glances back, giving us look at his face: it is 17 LARRY Gopnik.

You following this?... Okay?.. So... Heh-heh... This part is exciting... Students follow along, bored. LARRY continues to write. . So, okay. So. So if that's that, then we can do this, right? Is that right? Isn't that right? And that's Schrodinger's paradox, right? Is the cat dead or is the c not dead? Okay?
LARRY is entering the physics department office. The depa secretary wheels her castored chair away from her typing.
Messages, Professor Gopnik. He takes the three phone messages.
Thank you, Natalie. Oh-CLIVE. Come in. A Korean graduate student who was been waiting on a strai chair rises.
He is flipping through the messages. Absently:

So, uh, what can I do for you? The messages: WHILE YOU WERE OUT Dick Dutton OF Columbia Record Club 18 CALLED. REGARDING: "Please call." WHILE YOU WERE OUT Sy Ableman CALLED. REGARDING "Let's talk." WHILE YOU WERE OUT CLIVE Park CALLED. REGARDING: "Unjust test results." He crumples the last one.
Uh, Dr. Gopnik, I believe the results of Physics Mid-Term were unjust.
Uh-huh, how so?
I received an unsatisfactory grade. In fact: F, the faili grade.
Uh, yes. You failed the mid-term. That's accurate.
Yes, but this is not just. I was unaware to be examined o the mathematics.
Well-you can't do physics without mathematics, really, can you.
If I receive failing grade I lose my scholarship, and fee shame. I understand the physics. I understand the dead ca
(SURPRISED)

You understand the dead cat? 19 CLIVE nods gravely. But... you... you can't really understand the physics without understanding the math. The math tells how it really works. That's the real thing; the stories I give y class are just illustrative; they're like, fables, say, t give you a picture. An imperfect model. I mean-even I don't understand the dead cat. The math is how it really works. CLIVE shakes his head, dubious.
Very difficult... very difficult...
Well, I... I'm sorry, but I... what do you propose?
Passing grade.
No no, I-
Or perhaps I can take the mid-term again. Now I know it covers mathematics.
Well, the other students wouldn't like that, would they. one student gets to retake the test til he gets a grade h likes. CLIVE impassively considers this.
Secret test. LARRY wraps a hand wearily over his eyes.
. No, I'm afraid- 20
Hush-hush.
No, that's just not workable. I'm afraid we'll just have bite the bullet on this thing, CLIVE, and-

Very troubling. He rises. . very troubling... He goes to the door, shaking his head, as LARRY looks on He leaves. LARRY stares at the open door. The secretary outside, her to us, types on. LARRY. looks stupidly around his own office, shakes his h He picks up the phone message from Sy Ableman-"Let's talk dials. As he dials his other hand wanders over the papers on the desktop. There is a plain white envelope on the desk. LARRY picks as the phone rings through. A ring is clipped short and a warm basso-baritone rumbles the line: Phone Voice Sy Ableman.
Hello, Sy, LARRY Gopnik.
(MOURNFUL)
LARRY. How are you, my friend. LARRY picks idly at the envelope.
Good, how've you been, Sy? 21 Inside the envelope: a thick sheaf of one-hundred-dollar
Oh fine. Shall we talk LARRY. LARRY reacts to the money.
(into phone) What?! Oh! Sorry! I, uh-call back! He slams down the phone.

He rushes out the door, through the secretarial area, and the hallway, and looks up toward the elevators. Empty. He looks at the stuffed envelope he still holds. He goes back to the departmental office. The secretary si She glances at him and, as she goes back to her typing:
Sy Ableman just called. Said he got disconnected.
A hand enters to knock. Man's Voice Out in a minute! SARAH, the sixteen-year-old girl who has just knocked, ro her eyes.
I gotta wash my hair! I'm going out tonight!
Out in a minute! 22
Jesus Christ! She stomps down the hall.
Judith, a woman of early middle age, is at the stove. SAR
W is Uncle Arthur always in the bathroom?
He has to drain his sebacious cyst. You know that. Will you set the table?
Why can't he do it in the basement? Or go out in the garage!
We are raking the exterior of an orange school bus as it along. Hebrew characters on the side identify it-to some, anyway.

We are locked down on DANNY as the bus rattles like an ol squeaking, grinding gears, belching exhaust. DANNY and the children around hi and pitch about but, from their lack of reaction, seem used to it. They raise their voices to be heard over the engine noise the various stress noises in the chassis and a transistor radio somewhere that plays J Airplane.
I had twenty bucks in it too. Inside the case. 23 Mark Sallerson Twenty bucks! How come.
I bought a lid from Mike Fagle. Couple weeks ago. I still owed him twenty. Mark Sallerson He already gave you the pot?

Yeah but a couple weeks ago my funding got cut off. Fagle said he'd pound the crap out of me if I didn't pay up. Howard Altar What funding got cut off? Where do you get your money? Another boy, with thick glasses, is Ronnie Nudell. Ronnie Nudell What happened? Mark Sallerson Rabbi Turchik took his radio. Had money in it. Ronnie Nudell That fucker!

Yeah. I think he said he was confiscating it. Ronnie Nudell He's a fucker! Where do you get your money? Mark Sallerson Mike Fagle's gonna kick his ass. Last week he pounded the crap out of Seth Seddlemeyer. 24 Ronnie Nudell He's a fucker! Mark Sallerson Fagle? Or Seth Seddlemeyer? Ronnie Nudell They're both f ickers!
A hand enters to knock. Uncle Arthur's Voice Out in a minute!
Are you still in there?! Uncle Arthur I, uh.. . Just a minute!
I've gotta wash my hair! I'm going out tonight, to the ho Uncle Arthur Okay!

LARRY pulls into the driveway and gets out of the car. Th of a lawn mower. He looks. His point-of-view: Gar Brandt, the next-door neighbor, is his lawn. He has a buzz cut and is wearing a white T-shirt. Another noise competes with the lawn mower: rattling, squ gear-grinding. The orange school bus with Hebrew lettering pulls up across t Its door opens with a pneumatic hiss to discharge a passenger. 25
LARRY sits in. His wife and two children are already seat There is one empty place. LARRY projects:
Arthur! A muffled voice:
Yeah!
Dinner!
Okay! Out in a minute!
We should wait.
Are you kidding! They start eating.
Mr. Brandt keeps mowing part of our lawn.
Does that matter?
What?
Is it important? LARRY shrugs.
It's just odd. 26
Any news on your tenure?
I think they'll give me tenure.
You think.
(EQUABLY)
Well, I don't know. These things aren't, you know.. .
No, I don't know. Which is why I ask.
Mom, how long is Uncle Arthur staying with us?
Ask your father.

Twilight. LARRY is stepping onto a hose as he unwheels it from the of a traveling sprinkler, laying out an are to cover the back yard. Intermittent th from next door: Gar Brandt and his son, who also has a buzz cut and a whi throw a baseball back and forth. Gar Brandt throws hard. The ball pops in boy's mitt.
Ow. LARRY walks over to the boundary defined by the fresh mow He sights down it. Gar Brandt looks over his shoulder at LARRY, looking. Gar is expressionless. He 27 goes back to throwing.
Ow.

Evening. Lights on. LARRY sits at the kitchen table, a br open on the chair next to him. Blue books-examination booklets-are spread on the ta in front of him. He reads, occasionally making marginal scribbles, grading. From off, faint and dulled by intervening walls, rock mus somewhere in the house DANNY is listening to the Jefferson Airplane. The clink of teaspoon against china as LARRY stirs his te looks up at a noise: JUDY enters.
Honey.
(ABSENT)
Honey.
Did you talk to Sy? Still absent, without looking up:
Sy?-Sy Ableman!-That's right, he called, but I-
You didn't talk to him.
No, I-
You know the problems you and I have been having. Sympathetic, but still absent: 28
Mm.

Well, Sy and I have become very close. This brings LARRY's head up. He focuses on JUDY, puzzled. elaborates: In.short: I think it's time to start talking about a divo LARRY stares at her. A long beat. At length, trying to digest:
. Sy Ableman!
This is not about Sy.
You mentioned Sy!
Don't twist my words. We-
A divorce-what have I done! I haven't done anything- What have I done!
LARRY, don't be a child. You haven't "done" anything. I haven't "done" anything.
Yes! Yes! We haven't done anything! And I-I'm probably about to get tenure!
Nevertheless, there have been problems. As you know.
And things have changed. And then-Sy Ableman. Sy has come into my life. And now-
Come into your-what does that mean?! You, you, you, you barely know him!
We've known the Ablemans for fifteen years.
Yes, but you you said we hadn't done anything! JUDY suddenly is stony:
I haven't done anything. This is not some flashy fling. This is not about woopsy-doopsy. LARRY stares at her.
Sy Ableman! From down the hall, a knock on a door. A muffled voice:
Out in a minute!
Look, I didn't know any other way of breaking it to you. Except to tell you. And treat you like an adult. Is that wrong? LARRY does not seem to be listening. His eyes roam the ro he thinks.
Where do I sleep? JUDY narrows her eyes. 30
What?
Arthur's on the couch!
Look. Sy feels that we should-
Esther is barely cold!
Esther died three years ago. And it was a loveless marriage. Sy wants a Gett. This derails the conversation. LARRY stares, trying to pi the thread.
. A what?
A ritual divorce. He says it's very important. Without a Gett I'm an Aguna.
A what? What are you talking about? She turns to go, shaking her head, peeved:
You always act so surprised. As she leaves: I have begged you to see the Rabbi.

LARRY has fallen asleep at the kitchen table, face-down i pile of blue books. Cold blue light sweeps across him and he looks up. 31 A short, balding middle-aged man in flannel pyjamas and a flannel dressing gown stands in front of the open refrigerator holding an open of orange juice. He tips the jar back to drink, his free hand holding a balled-up towel to back of his neck LARRY stares at him.
LARRY enters the departmental office. His eyes are red-ri and dark-bagged. He has beard stubble. The department's secretary wheels her castored chair away her typing.
Messages, Professor Gopnik. He takes the two phone messages.

LARRY looks at the messages: WHILE YOU WERE OUT Dick Dutton OF Columbia Record Club CALLED. REGARDING: "2Ad attempt. Please call." WHILE YOU WERE OUT Sy Ableman CALLED. REGARDING "Let's have a good talk." A knock brings his look up.

Yes-thanks for coming, CLIVE. CLIVE Park enters the office. 32 . Have a seat. LARRY uses a key to open the top left desk drawer. He tak the envelope. We had, I think, a good talk, the other day, but you left something that-
I didn't leave it.
Well--you don't even know what I was going to say.
I didn't leave anything. I'm not missing anything. I know where everything is. LARRY looks at him, trying to formulate a thought.
Well... then, CLIVE, where did this come from? He waves the envelope. . This is here, isn't it? CLIVE looks at it gravely.
Yes, sir. That is there.
This is not nothing, this is something.
Yes sir. That is something. A beat. . What is it.
You know what it is! You know what it is! I believe. And 33 you know I can't keep it, CLIVE.
Of course, sir.
I'll have to pass it on to Professor Finkle, along with m suspicions about where it came from. Actions have consequences.
Yes. Often.
Always! Actions always have consequences! He pounds the desk for emphasis. In this office, actions have consequences!
Yes sir.
Not just physics. Morally.
Yes.
And we both know about your actions.
No sir. I know about my actions.
I can interpret, CLIVE. I know what you meant me to understand.
Meer sir my sir. LARRY cocks his head. 34
. Meer sir my sir?
(careful enunciation) Mere... surmise. Sir. He gravely shakes his head. . Very uncertain.
A hand lays it onto a slowly spinning vinyl record. Through scratches and pops, a solo tenor starts a mournfu chant. Close on the sleeve: Rabbi Youssele Rosenblatt Chants Your Haftorah Portion

Rabbi Youssele wears a caftan and a felt hat and has sad They peer out from the dark beard that covers most of the rest of his face like eyes peering out of the woods. Wider, on DANNY, in his bedroom, evening. He lifts the to on the portable turntable. He chants the passage. He drops the tone arm at the same place; Rabbi Youssele c the passage again. DANNY listens, eyes narrowed. He lifts the tone arm and c the passage again. He replays the passage again; before he can lift the tone to echo it his door bursts open. Rabbi Youssele continues to chant. 35
You little brat fucker! You snuck twenty bucks out of my drawer!
Studying torah! Asshole!
You little brat! I'm telling Dad!
Oh yeah? You gonna tell him you've been sneaking it out of his wallet?
All right, you know what I'm gonna do? You little brat? I you don't give it back? We hear the thunk of the front door opening. DANNY stands
Dad?
LARRY is entering with his briefcase. As he stows it in t closet DANNY's voice continues, off:
Dad, you gotta fix the aerial. Judith emerges from the kitchen.
Hello LARRY, have you thought about a lawyer?
Honey, please! DANNY emerges from the hall.
36 We're not getting channel four at all.
(to Judith) Can we discuss it later?
I can't get F Troop.
LARRY, the children know. Do you think this is some secre Do you think this is something we're going to keep quiet? SARAH enters.
Dad, Uncle Arthur is in the bathroom again! And I=m going to the hole at eight! She hits DANNY on the back of the head.
Stop it!

Don.

Well, the way I look at it, it's an opportunity for me to really sit down and figure things out, and, and, look at world afresh instead of just, you know, settling for the routine, tired old way of looking at things. Don Milgram stares at him.
. Really?
(DEFLATING)

Oh.

Oh.

text: It dominates a small suburban strip mall. Rabbi Nachtner continues in voice-over as we cut to a smo glass door that identifies Leon Sussman, DDS. He's a delivery dispatcher for the Star and Tribune with chronic mandicular deterioration. The grinding guitar solo from Jefferson Airplane's "Bear scores the narrative. Well, the mold dries and Lee is examining it one day 83 before fabricating an appliance... Another day: Dr. Sussman is sitting at his desk examining lower mold. He notices something unusual. . He notices something unusual. Sussman reaches up for the loupe attached to his eyeglass There seems to be something engraved on the inside of the patient's lower incisors... He flips down the loupe. His eyes are hugely magnified as stares. Sure enough, it's writing. Sussman squints. His point-of-view: Tiny incised Hebrew letters: smli12nn
He confirms with a nod. Rabbi Nachtner This in a goy's mouth, LARRY.

The Rabbi's narrative continues. Rabbi Nachtner Tet resh nun lamed nun shin tsayin. What is that-tiranu linoshets? "Help me"? Is that what it says? Or is it a name? It's not Kraus's name. Sussman flips the loupe away and looks off, haunted. He r He checks the mold, just to be sure. Oh, it's there all 84 right... A dental mirror is dipped into the horse-shoe-shaped hard paste of the mold. It pans tiny letters that stand out in relief, right-side around mirror: yw .rin Sussman leans back, thinking. He calls the goy back on the pretense of needing addition measurements for the appliance... Close on Kraus grinning as he shakes Sussman's hand in th area. Sussman gestures to invite Kraus back to the examination room. Sussman chats, affecting nonchalance. In the examination room, leaning over Kraus in the chair, dentist is indeed chatting with seeming casualness. Notice any other problems with your teeth? Anything peculiar, et cetera? Sussman takes a dental mirror. No. No. No. Visited any other dentist recently? He looks in Kraus' mouth with the mirror: Ym nn Sussman frowns. There it is. "Help me"? He leans back. Sussman goes home. Can Sussman eat? No. Sussman sits at the kitchen table, untouched food in fron him. His wife chats volubly while Sussman stares into space. Can Sussman sleep? No. 85 Sussman is in bed, pyjamas buttoned to the neck, staring ceiling. What does it mean? Is it a message for him, for Sussman? And if so, from whom? Does Sussman know? Sussman doesn't know. Back in the dental office Sussman pulls boxes containing molds off the shelf. Sussman looks at the molds of his other patients, goy and Jew alike, seeking other messages. He finds none. He looks in his own mouth... Close on Sussman in front of a mirror straining to see th of a reflection of the dental mirror he holds in his own mouth. . Nothing. His wife's mouth... Sussman's wife lies asleep on her back, her mouth open, s softly. Sussman, in pyjamas but with his glasses on and loupe in place, lies her in bed, supporting himself with one arm thrown across her body. He leans awk in, carefully lowering a dental mirror into his wife's open mouth. . Nothing. It is a singular event. A mystery. The Jefferson Airplane guitar solo is heating up. But Sussman is an educated man. Not the world's greatest sage, maybe, no Rabbi Minda, but he knows a thing or two from the Zohar and the Caballah. He knows every Hebrew letter has its numeric equivalent. Sussman, still in his pyjamas is sitting at the kitchen t scribbling on a tablet of lined paper. Close on the paper: the Hebrew letters have been transcri into their numeric
496-2428 Nachtner continues in voice-over: 86 Seven digits-a phone number maybe? Sussman reaches for the phone. He hesitates a moment, the . Sussman dials. It rings.

In a grocery store. A man in short sleeves reaches for th Rabbi Nachtner It's a Red Owl grocery store in Bloomington. Hello? Do you know a goy named Kraus? Russel Kraus? The store manager is shaking his head. Where have I called? The Red Owl. In Bloomington. Thanks so much. The manager, puzzled, hangs up. Sussman thinks, am I supposed to go to the Red Owl, to receive a further sign? He goes... In the parking lot of the Red Owl Sussman, wearing a shor fedora, emerges from his car. It is an unremarkable grocery store in a su mall. It's a Red Owl. Inside Sussman, in his fedora, gazes around. Groceries. What have you. A service alley behind the store: dumpsters, wind-blown g Sussman looking. On the wall behind the store, a stain... There is an old, rather nondescript stain of some liquid against the back wall and long since dribbled away. . Could be a nun sofit... Or maybe not... The parking lot again: Sussman gets back in his car. 87 Sussman goes home. What does it mean? He has to find out, if he's ever to sleep again. Sussman again, in pyjamas buttoned to the neck, lies in h staring at the ceiling. He goes to see the Rabbi, Nachtner. He comes in and sits right where you're sitting now. Sussman is indeed sitting across from Rabbi Nachtner, jus we've seen LARRY sitting. What does it mean, Rabbi? Is it a sign from Hashem? "Help me." I, Sussman, should be doing something to help this goy? Doing what? The teeth don't say. I should know without asking? Or maybe I'm supposed to help people generally-lead a more righteous life? Is the answer in cabalah? In torah? Or is there even a question? Tell me, Rabbi-what can such a sign mean? Nachtner-not the narrating Nachtner but the Nachtner in t and considers.
Staring at the Rabbi. He waits a good beat. He prompts:
So what did you tell him? The Rabbi seems surprised by the question. Rabbi Nachtner Sussman?
Yes! Rabbi Nachtner Is it. . relevant? 88

Well-isn't that why you're telling me? Rabbi Nachtner Mm. Okay. Nachtner says, look.. . We are back in the scene, narrated by voice-over, of the silently advising the fretful Sussman. . The teeth, we don't know. A sign from Hashem, don't know. Helping others, couldn't hurt. LARRY's voice-over question plays over Sussman asking the thing: LARRY (of]) But is that what it meant?-tet resh nun lamed nun shin isayin, was it "Help me"? or a number? Or was it Rabbi Nachtner (off) We can't know everything. Sussman stares blankly at the Rabbi. A beat. LARRY (of]) It sounds like you don't know Mthing!
Smiling equably at LARRY. He reacts to the ejaculation wi shrug. LARRY scowls.

First I should tell you, then I shouldn't. 89 LARRY, exasporated, changes tack:

In his office. Working on different patients as the Rabbi his voice-over. Rabbi Nachtner What would happen? Not much. He went back to work. For a while he checked every patient's teeth for new messages; didn't see any; in time, he found he'd stopped checking. Sussman, at home, chats with his wife over dinner. . These questions that are bothering you, LARRY-maybe they're like a toothache. We feel them for a while, then they go away. Sussman lies in bed sleeping, smiling, an arm thrown acro wife.
Dissatisfied.

I don't want it to just go away! I want an answer! Rabbi Nachtner The answer! Sure! We all want the answer! But Hashem doesn't owe us the answer, LARRY. Hashem doesn't owe us anything. The obligation runs the other way.

Why does he make us feel the questions if he's not gonna give us any answers? Rabbi Nachtner smiles at LARRY for a beat. 90 Rabbi Nachtner He hasn't told me. LARRY rubs his face, frustrated. A last question occurs to him:
And what happened to the goy? Rabbi Nachtner's forebearing smile fades into puzzlement. Rabbi Nachtner The goy? Who cares?
The modern synagogue grafted onto a patch of prairie. An echoing voice rings out:
Sy Ableman was a serious man!

In close-up he gazes around, weighing the effect of the w just delivered. After a long beat during which he seeks to establish eye with as much of his audience as possible: Rabbi Nachtner . Sy Ableman was a man devoted to his community... Wider shows Rabbi Nachtner up on the bema. He and the con face each other across a casket down at floor level. . to torah study... LARRY sits among the congregants, his gaze fixed on a poi 91 . to his beloved wife Esther until, three years ago, she passed.. . LARRY's point-of-view: JUDY is visible from 3 behind. She a few rows ahead looking grimly up at the rabbi. . and to his duty, as he saw it. Where does such a man go? A tzadik-who knows, maybe even a lamid vovnik-a man beloved by all, a man who despised the frivolous? Could such a serious man... simply... disappear? The words echo. Again the rabbi gazes around, as if awaiting answer.

. We speak of L'olam ha-ba, the World to Come. Not heaven. Not what the gentiles think of as afterlife. "L'olam ha-ba." What is L'olam ha-ba? Where is L'olam ha-ba? Well: it is not a geoaraphic place, certainly. Like-Canada. Murmured chuckles from the congregation. Nor is it the eretz zavat chalav ood'vash-the land flowin with milk and honey, for we are not promised a personal reward, a gold star, a first-class VIP lounge where we ge milk and cookies to eternity! More chuckles. L'olam ha-ba... is in the bosom of Abraham. L'olam ba- ba is in the soul of this community which nurtured Sy Ableman and to which Sy Ableman now returns. That's right, he returns. Because he still inspires us Ableman returns. Because his memory instructs us Ableman returns. Because his thoughts illuminate our days and way Sy Ableman returns. The frivolous man may vanish without a ripple but Sy Ableman? Sy Ableman was a serious man... 92 A sob echoes through the sanctuary. LARRY looks at Judith, who stifles further sobs with a ha . As you know, the mourner's kaddish does not mention the dead. It praises Hashem; it praises what abides. And Sy Ableman, whose spirit will continue to assist us in tikkun olam, is with us even now, a serious man who would say as we now say Yiskadal v'yiskadash sh'may rabah... Look. Tell Gopnik-you know, Arthur Gopnik-he's breaking the law. We're not arresting him now but next time we will. Gambling is against the law in this state. That's just the way it is. All right. Go back to your...
Sorry, sir.
A minute later. The family-except for Judith, whose weepi off-sits around the card table. A long beat. At length: 94
Dad, we get Channel 4 now but not Channel 7.

That doesn't make it right! And you-
He won a lot of money, Dad! The Mentaculus really works! LARRY's gaze swings onto his son.
You knew about it?!
Well, um...
They must have finked me out. They knew I could just keep on winning, so a couple weeks ago they blackballed me, and now they've-
What did you do with the money you won? Silence. Arthur sneaks a look at DANNY. LARRY looks back and forth between them. . What's going on? Arthur shrugs.
95 I didn't want it. DANNY said he could use it

(knowing nod) I know about the records.

Hey! What's going on!

Brat!

Ali! Struck by a thought he leaps up and bolts from the room.
DANNY! You weren't excused! We're still talking!

DANNY! We're sitting Shiva!
LARRY, sitting across from Don, has his head buried in hi on the desktop.

(MUFFLED)

These are not pleasant people. Judith is free of course t retain whoever she... I take it you don't talk to her? LARRY raises his head, squinting against the light.
It's hard. I think she emptied our bank account. I tried ask her about it, very civilly.
Mm.
She, uh...
Yeah, yeah you better open an account in your name only, put your paychecks in there from here on out. Til we know where we stand.
Can I?
Oh, absolutely!
That's not, um, dishonest?
Oh, absolutely! You, uh-
I hate to say this, but I think she's also been sneaking out of my wallet.

. Have you seen the Rabbi?

Getting old.

LARRY, you're fine. It's a bump in the road. Was Nachtner helpful at all? LARRY gives a helpless shrug. Don rolls his eyes. . What-did he tell you about the goy's teeth? A knock on the door. Solomon Schlutz is a large man in shirtsleeves and suspen He has the smooth impassive face of a sphynx with a pipe clenched in its te He glides into the room, a sheaf of files tucked under on . .Sol? Solomon Schlutz's face now passes from the red end of the to the purple. Solomon Schlutz Nnnnff! The pipe clatters out of his hand. The hand grabs at his shirt front. . Glufffl... Thank you. I'm fine. He puts the envelope in the desk drawer and closes it. 102 Arlen Finkle Uh-huh. Well. As you know, the tenure committee meets next Wednesday to make its final determinations. If

I am not- Arlen Finkle We don't make moral judgments!

. Okay. Arlen Finkle Okay. Okay. We, uh, we decide on Wednesday, so if there's anything you want to submit in support of your tenure application, we should have it by then. That's all

I haven't published. Arlen Finkle Uh-huh.

Okay. Okay. Wednesday. Arlen Finkle Okay. Don't worry. Doing nothing is not bad. Ipso facto.
Sure. 104

. and that means... so that... from which we derive... His glances back toward the class show that he is wearier more haggard than ever. There is also something odd about his posture. Wider as he finishes and straightens up, revealing that h been stooping to write across the very bottom of the board. The equation covers every inch of the classroom-wide thre chalkboard.
